    # Pronunciation: The Basics (Part Two)

    So you're here again! willing to learn more about pronunciation! that's great! Let's go then üòÉ!


    • Short Vowels: in German spelling two consonants after a vowel will normally indicate it is short. Example: Hand means Hand | Bett means Bed | Pilz means Mushroom | Schloss means Lock | T√∂chter means Daughters | Zunge means Tongue | Fl√ºsse means Rivers.

    • Long Vowels: only one consonant after a vowel indicates it is long. Example: Vater means Father | VaÃàter means Fathers | Lesen means Read | Liga means League | Rot means Red | SchoÃàn means Beautiful | Gut means Good | Tr√ºbe means Cloudy.

    TIP

    Sometimes you come accross words like Zahlen, means Numbers, and you think: well, that's a short a because there're two consonants after it, the h and the l, right? The answer is no, the a here is long, because the h is silent üòâ.

    Another thing to pay attention to is the consonant sound; for example the ch is made of two letters, but it's pronounced as one sound; an example of that would be Buch, which means Book. The u is long here as well.


    # Consonants in German

    Because we know English, and because German looks like English; we might fall for some tricks here and there; but fear not lady; we're here to learn how to avoid that üòâ.


    • B: it's like the English B, but if you see it in the end of a word, then it is P! Example: ab means from | Lob means Praise.

    • Chs: this combination is pronounced like the English x. Example: Sechs means Six | Fuchs means Fox.

    • Ch: at the beginning of loanwords is pronounced like k, sh or the soft german ch; depending on the source language. Example: Chaos means Chaos | Chance means Chance | China means China.

    TIP

    I don't think you have to worry about that at all! You just have to look for the word you wanna learn, and then learn how the ch in it should be pronounced üòâ.


    • Ck: you find this in the middle and the end of German words, and it pronounced as the English K. Example: Lecker means Delicious | Fleck means Stain.

    • D: it's like the English D, but it's a T if you see it in the end of a word. Example: Gold means Gold | Hand means Hand.

    • G: at the beginning or in the middle of words is pronounced as ⁄Ø; where it's K in the end of the word. Example: Gang means Gear | Fliegen means Fly.

    • ig: at the end of the word is pronounced like German ich. Example: KoÃànig means King | Lustig means Funny.

    • Pf: that one looks weird, but it's commmon in German, and pronounced just like the way it looks üòÑ! Example: Pferd means Hourse | Kopf means Head.

    • Ph: is still used in some loanwords and is pronounced as F. Example: Photograph means Photographer | Philosophie means Philosophy.

    • Q: always occurs in combination with U, as in English, and together they are pronounced kv. Example: QualitaÃàt means Quality | Quelle means Source.

    • S: at the beginning and in the middle of a word is pronounced z; however at the end of a word is pronounced s; ss is always pronounced s too. Example: Sollen means Should | Lesen means Read | Glas means Glass | Schoss means Lap.

    • T: in French loanwords ending in -tion, t is pronounced ts. Example: Nation means Nation | Station means Station.

    • Tsch: is pronounced like tch in butcher. Example: Deutsch means German | Tsch√ºss means Bye.

    • V: I know that I told you this is f, but it can be also a v in loanwords. Example: Vase means Vase | Video means Video.

    • X: is rare in German, is always pronounced ks. Example: Nix means Nothing.

    • Z: is ts, however you might see it comes next to the letter t, that doesn't do anything special, the z is still pronounced as ts üòÉ. Example: Platz means Place.


    With that, we're officially completed the German alphabets and the way they pronounced üòÉ. I know it was boring, but we had to go through that.

    Now we're out of that, let's jump to pronouns in German, shall we! üòâ
